contextId.information: Paul is speaking to the Corinthians as if they were one person, so all instances of "you" here are singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
contextId.quote: between you ... do you have that you did not ... you have freely ... do you boast ... you had not

contextId.information: Paul is speaking to the Corinthians as if they were one person, so all these instances of "you" and the command "do not seek" here are singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
contextId.quote: Are you bound ... Do not seek ... Are you free ... Do not seek ... you do ... you have

contextId.information: Paul is speaking to the Corinthians as if they were one person, so these words are singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
Paul is speaking to the Corinthians as if they were one person, so the word "your" here is singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
Moses was speaking to the Israelites as if they were one person, so this command is singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

Some translations put these words in parentheses because 1) the form of "you" here is singular, but Paul uses the plural form immediately before and after and 2) the words "For why should my freedom be judged by another's conscience?" seem to build on "eat whatever is set before you without asking questions of conscience" ([[:en:bible:notes:1co:10:25|10:27]]) rather than "the other person's conscience." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
contextId.quote: But if someone ... the other person's conscience

contextId.information: Though "you" is singular here, Paul is addressing everyone who prays only in the spirit, but not with the mind. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
contextId.quote: you praise God ... you are giving thanks ... you are saying

Paul is speaking to the Corinthians as if they were one person, so both instances of "you" here are singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
